HomePage.Overview of Cashu and its Concepts: Overview of Cashu and its Concepts
HomePage.title: classu.cash
HomePage.subtitle: Cashu is privacy-preserving digital cash using blind signatures
HomePage.Bob signs tokens: Bob signs tokens without seeing their content, ensuring privacy. The token is a combination of Alice's secret + Bob's signature. When Carol redeems it, Bob can verify it's valid but can't link it back to Alice.
HomePage.PRIVACY: Bob: PRIVACY: Bob doesn't know Carol's token came from Alice!
HomePage.ph1 description: Alice creates a secret message and gets Bob (the mint operator) to blindly sign it
HomePage.ph1 st3: Bob signs the blinded message (without seeing it)
HomePage.ph1 st4: Alice unblinds to get a valid token
HomePage.ph2 description: Alice sends the token privately to Carol, off-chain
HomePage.ph2 st1: Alice sends the valid token to Carol
HomePage.ph2 st3: No blockchain needed - instant and private
HomePage.ph3 description: Carol redeems the token with Bob and receives funds
HomePage.ph3 st1: Carol sends the token back to Bob
HomePage.ph3 st2: Bob verifies the token hasn't been spent
HomePage.ph3 st3: Bob checks the spent secrets database
HomePage.ph3 st4: Carol receives funds, token is marked as spent
HomePage.ph3 st5: Bob doesn't know the token came from Alice (PRIVACY!)

nut00.title: Notation, Utilization, and Terminology
nut00.subtitle: Notation, Utilization, and Terminology
nut00.bdhkeSt_1_description: The mint publishes its public key K, derived from private key k and generator point G
nut00.bdhkeSt_2_description: Alice picks a secret x, hashes it to curve point Y, then blinds it with random factor r
nut00.bdhkeSt_3_description: Alice sends the blinded message B_ to Bob without revealing her secret
nut00.bdhkeSt_4_description: Bob signs the blinded message without seeing the actual secret
nut00.bdhkeSt_5_description: Bob sends back the blind signature to Alice
nut00.bdhkeSt_6_description: Alice removes the blinding factor to get the final signature C
nut00.bdhkeSt_7_description: Alice can now send the pair (secret, signature) as a token to Carol
nut00.bdhkeSt_8_description: Bob verifies the token is valid and marks the secret as spent
nut00.v_alice_r_desc: Random value to blind the secret
nut00.This specification defines: This specification defines the core notation, cryptographic models, and terminology used throughout the Cashu protocol for privacy-preserving digital cash.
nut00.The protocol uses: The protocol uses Blind Diffie-Hellmann Key Exchange (BDHKE) to enable the mint to sign tokens without seeing their content. This ensures that when Carol redeems a token, Bob can verify its validity but cannot link it back to Alice.
nut00.Bob signs the token: Bob signs the token without ever seeing the secret x. When Carol redeems it, Bob can verify it's valid but cannot determine who originally created it.
nut00.Deterministically maps a: Deterministically maps a message to a curve point
nut00.Sent from Alice to: Sent from Alice to Bob for minting or swapping
nut00.Keyset ID from: Keyset ID from which to expect signature
nut00.Sent from Bob to Alice after signing: Sent from Bob to Alice after signing
nut00.Used by Alice to spend tokens: Used by Alice to spend tokens
nut00.For NFC transmission: For NFC transmission, tokens use a binary prefix
nut00.Part of the Cashu Protocol Specification: Part of the Cashu Protocol Specification

nut01.title: Mint public key exchange
nut01.subtitle: Mint public key exchange
nut01.description_detail: Alice (wallet) receives Bob's (mint) public keys via GET /v1/keys to unblind blind signatures (NUT-00).
nut01.active_keysets_detail: The mint only responds with 'active' keysets, which are used for new signatures. Inactive keysets are accepted for inputs but not used for new outputs.
nut01.endpoint_detail: The primary endpoint for requesting the mint's active keysets.
nut01.response_detail: The response contains an array of active keysets.
nut01.currency_units_detail: Mints can support various units for minting (NUT-04) and melting (NUT-05).
nut01.minor_unit_rule_detail: For Bitcoin and ISO 4217 currencies, Keyset amount values MUST represent an amount in the Minor Unit of that currency (e.g., sat for btc, cent for usd).
nut01.keyset_generation_detail: Keysets are generated by the mint, identified by an 'id' computable from its public keys (NUT-02).
nut01.keys_map_detail: Keysets are maps of '{<amount_i> : <mint_pubkey_i>}'. The public key MUST use the compressed Secp256k1 format.

nut02.title: Keysets and Fees
nut02.subtitle: Mint Public Key Management
nut02.Protocol Definition Description: This NUT defines how mints manage multiple sets of public keys (keysets) and how fees are calculated for transactions.
nut02.Keyset Management Description: Supports key rotation, multiple currencies, and usage fees.
nut02.ID Desc: An identifier derived from the mint's public keys.
nut02.ID Detail 1: Derived by anyone knowing the public keys.
nut02.ID Detail 2: Present in Proof, BlindedMessage, and BlindSignature.
nut02.ID Detail 3: Allows wallets to identify which mint created the token.
nut02.Active Desc: Determines if new ecash can be generated.
nut02.Active Detail 2: Active=False: Accepted as inputs (spending) but not for new outputs.
nut02.Active Detail 3: Wallets should prioritize spending inactive tokens to rotate keys.
nut02.Unit Desc: The currency unit supported by this specific keyset (e.g., sat, usd). A mint can have multiple keysets for different units.
nut02.Fee Desc: input_fee_ppk: Fee charged per input spent.
nut02.Ppk Desc: Fees are calculated per input (Proof) spent in a transaction.
nut02.Ppk Example Note: Example: 100 ppk = 0.1 units per input. Spending 3 inputs = 300 ppk total. ceil(300 / 1000) = 1 unit fee.
nut02.Calculation Note: Note: Floating point division is discouraged due to non-determinism.
nut02.Derivation Step 1: Sort public keys by their amount in ascending order.
nut02.Derivation Step 2: Concatenate all public keys into one byte array.
nut02.Derivation Step 4: Take the first 14 characters of the hex-encoded hash.
nut02.API Keyset Desc: Returns a list of all keysets the mint supports. Used by wallets to sync state.
nut02.API Keys Desc: Returns the map of amounts to public keys for a specific keyset ID.
nut02.Wallet Step 1 Desc: If no keys exist, call GET /v1/keys to store all current keys.
nut02.Wallet Step 2 Desc: Call GET /v1/keysets to see active/inactive flags.
nut02.Wallet Step 3 Desc: If a new keyset ID appears, fetch it via GET /v1/keys/'{id}.
nut02.Wallet Step 4 Desc: If a keyset becomes inactive, update DB and prioritize spending from it.

nut03.title: Swap tokens
nut03.subtitle: Swap tokens
nut03.Part of the Cashu Protocol Specification: Part of the Cashu Protocol Specification
nut03.Protocol Definition Desc: The swap operation is the most important component of the Cashu system. A swap operation consists of multiple inputs (Proofs) and outputs (BlindedMessages). Mints verify and invalidate the inputs and issue new promises (BlindSignatures).
nut03.Swap Functionality Desc: A swap allows for splitting or combining tokens (Proofs) to reach a target amount, or to invalidate incoming tokens and get new ones in return.
nut03.Swap to Send Desc: User Alice uses the swap to reshape her tokens into denominations that allow her to send a precise amount to Carol, keeping the remainder as change.
nut03.Alice Example Desc: Alice has 64 sat in [32, 16, 16]. She wants to send 40 sat.
nut03.Alice Swap Detail: Alice uses [16, 16, 32] as inputs and asks for [8, 32, 8, 16] as outputs. The first two tokens can now be combined to 40 sat. The inputs are invalidated.
nut03.Privacy Note Desc: To preserve privacy around the amount a client might want to send, the list of requested outputs SHOULD be ordered by amount in ascending order.
nut03.Swap to Receive Desc: User Carol can invalidate tokens received from Alice by sending them to the Mint to receive new BlindSignatures with an equivalent total in return. This finalizes the transaction.
nut03.Carol Swap Detail: Carol receives [32, 8] sat from Alice. She uses them as inputs for a swap and gets new outputs (e.g. [16, 16, 8]) from the Mint, invalidating Alice's tokens.

nut04.title: Mint tokens
nut04.subtitle: Two-step minting process (Quote & Mint)
nut04.Protocol Definition Desc: Minting tokens is a two-step process: requesting a mint quote and minting new tokens. This flow applies to all payment methods.
nut04.Minting Process Desc: A mandatory process that uses a quote/request/pay/mint structure to prevent attacks and support various payment methods.
nut04.Supported Methods Desc: Method-specific NUTs describe how to handle different payment methods.
nut04.Flow Step 1 Desc: Wallet requests a quote for the unit and method.
nut04.Flow Step 2 Desc: Mint responds with a quote ID and a payment request.
nut04.Flow Step 3 Desc: User pays the request using the specified method.
nut04.Flow Step 4 Desc: Wallet requests minting using the quote ID and new outputs.
nut04.Flow Step 5 Desc: Mint verifies payment and returns blind signatures.
nut04.API Quote Desc: The wallet requests a quote for the unit to mint, specifying the payment method.
nut04.API Mint Desc: The wallet executes the mint operation after the payment is verified.
nut04.Settings Desc: The settings for this NUT indicate the supported method-unit pairs for minting, exposed in the info response (NUT-06).
nut04.Setting Disabled Desc: Indicates whether minting is disabled for all methods.
nut04.Setting MinMax Desc: Minimum and maximum amount for an operation of this method-unit pair.
nut04.Setting Options Desc: Method-specific options defined in dedicated NUTs.
nut04.Unblinding Desc: Upon receiving the BlindSignatures from the mint, the wallet unblinds them to generate Proofs (using the blinding factor r and the mint's public key K, see BDHKE NUT-00). The wallet then stores these Proofs.
